messageBody:
--- mcphee@... wrote:
> Writing unit tests for the deterministic parts of the system is
> pretty
> standard fare, but it's not obvious how to reasonably test the
> stochastic parts of the system. At some level stochastic methods
> just
> aren't testable in the same way that deterministic methods are.

What random number generator are you using? My understanding
is that there are at least two in java (java.util.Random and
java.math.Random), and that at least one of these can be seeded
in such a way as to always generate the same string of numbers,
after the seed. I don't remember the detail off the top of my
head, but it is something like this:
random.seed(1L) ;
do_testing() ;
random.seed(1L) ;
do_testing() ;
The two calls to do_testing will do exactly the same thing,
even if they use the random number generator, because the random
number generator will do the same thing, because you seeded it
the same way.

Now, it sounds to me like you are a math focused dude, so you
may be using a custom random number generator. If so, I would
see if it has the repeatable behavior described above (for any
seed at all). If so, use it, as above. If not, consider stubbing
it out with a routine which has a file full of numbers. Maybe
10,000 numbers. The stub routine just reads the numbers out of
the file and returns them, starting over as required. Your
tests would look something like this:
my_random.useLibraryFile("file_full_of_numbers") ;
do_your_test() ;

The result of either of these plans, is a reproducable test
case. Each time it runs, you will get the exact same result.
This will work well for regression tests. For other sorts of
testing, I think your current plan (of measuring the randomness
of the results) is the right thing to do, even if it takes a
while.

I can describe these in more detail if you want. I have used
the file trick (a decade ago), but I think the seed trick is
much better, if it will work.

Joshua Levy
